Description: Boolean indicating whether the confirmation status of a planet has been questioned in the published literature
Planet name most commonly used in the literature
Stellar name most commonly used in the literature

Letter assigned to the planetary component of a planetary system. The first planet discovered in a system is given the designation "b" (the parent star is considered to be "a") and later planets are given subsequent letters
Number of stars in the planetary system
Number of confirmed planets in the planetary system
Boolean indicating whether the planet orbits a binary system
Method by which the planet was first identified
Year the planet was discovered
Location of observation of planet discovery (Ground or Space)
Boolean indicating if the planet host star exhibits radial velocity variations due to the planet
Boolean indicating if the planet transits its host star
Boolean indicating if the planet has been observed via imaging techniques
Time the planet takes to make a complete orbit around the host star or system, in Earth years
The longest radius of an elliptic orbit, equivalent to half of the major axis of the ellipse
Length of a line segment from the center of the planet to its surface, measured in units of radius of the Earth
Best planet mass estimate available, measured in Earth masses
Amount of mass per unit of volume of the planet
Amount by which the orbit of the planet deviates from a perfect circle
The equilibrium temperature of the planet as modeled by a black body heated only by its host star
Angle of the plane of the orbit relative to the plane perpendicular to the line-of-sight from Earth to the object
The size of the relative flux decrement caused by the orbiting body transiting in front of the star
The length of time from the moment the planet begins to cross the stellar limb to the moment the planet finishes crossing the stellar limb

Column Name: Ratio of Semi-Major Axis to Stellar Radius
Description: The distance between the planet and the star at mid-transit divided by the stellar radius
Half the peak-to-peak amplitude of variability in the stellar radial velocity (component of velocity in the line-of-sight from Earth to the object)
Classification of the star based on their spectral characteristics following the Morgan-Keenan system
Temperature of the star as modeled by a black body emitting the same total amount of electromagnetic radiation
Length of a line segment from the center of the star to its surface, measured in units of radius of the Sun
Amount of matter contained in the star, measured in units of masses of the Sun
Measurement of the metal content of the photosphere of the star as compared to the hydrogen content, relative to the Sun's photosphere content ratio
Amount of energy emitted by a star per unit time, measured in units of solar luminosities
Gravitational acceleration experienced at the stellar surface
The age of the host star, measured in billions of years
Amount of mass per unit of volume of the star
The time required for the planet host star to complete one rotation, assuming it is a solid body
Velocity of the star in the direction of the line of sight from Earth to the object
Angular change in position over time as seen from the center of mass of the Solar System, measured in units of milliarcseconds/year
Distance to the planetary system in units of lightyears
Right Ascension of the planetary system in decimal degrees
Declination of the planetary system in decimal degrees

Group: Photometry (of the system as a whole)
Description: Brightness of the host star as measured using the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) u band, in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the B (Johnson) band, in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) g band, in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the V (Johnson) band, in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) r band, in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) i band, in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS) z band, in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the J (2MASS) band, in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the H (2MASS) band, in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the K (2MASS) band in, units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the 3.4um (WISE) band, in units of magnitudes.
Brightness of the host star as measured using the 4.6um (WISE) band, in units of magnitudes.
Brightness of the host star as measured using the 12.um (WISE) band, in units of magnitudes
Brightness of the host star as measured using the 22.um (WISE) band, in units of magnitudes
